title: Coping with low data availability for social media crisis message categorisation. (arXiv:2305.17211v1 [cs.CL])
abstract: During crisis situations, social media allows people to quickly share information, including messages requesting help. This can be valuable to emergency responders, who need to categorise and prioritise these messages based on the type of assistance being requested. However, the high volume of messages makes it difficult to filter and prioritise them without the use of computational techniques. Fully supervised filtering techniques for crisis message categorisation typically require a large amount of annotated training data, but this can be difficult to obtain during an ongoing crisis and is expensive in terms of time and labour to create.  This thesis focuses on addressing the challenge of low data availability when categorising crisis messages for emergency response. tldr: 本文提出了在社交媒体危机信息分类中解决低数据可用性挑战的两种方法：领域适应和半监督分类，并且提出了一种可以进行跨语言分类的算法。
en_tdlr: This paper proposes two methods, domain adaptation and semi-supervised classification, to address the challenge of low data availability in social media crisis message categorisation and introduces a cross-lingual classification algorithm for information adaptation among multiple languages.
